bibl.title: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, December 5, 1941

div1.p: Taylor enjoyed Hench's “Conquest of Yellow Fever” and sees nothing in it to correct. He claims that Finlay wrote about the Aedes aegypti mosquito as a means of yellow fever transmission in 1881 and gave the method and technique for experimentation. He details his own involvement as a yellow fever volunteer.

div1.head: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, December 5, 1941

opener.dateline:
548 Grand Ave
Upper Darby, Pa
Dec 5th 1941

div1.p:
It was a pleasure for me to
receive the copy of your article on the “Conquest
of Yellow Fever”, as it will be a welcome addition
to the literature I have on the subject. (I had
previously received the picture of the Conquerors
of yellow fever in the Jour Amer Med Assoc.
of which I am a subscriber.)

The picture is very good, not only for
its artistic representation, but the succeeding
diagramatic numbering of the various personel,
makes it doubly valuable, and reflects much
credit on those who arranged it.

Will not go into all the persons
represented, but just select one, that is, Dr Carlos
J. Finlay. Am sure glad he was put on. It
was my pleasure to work with him (also Carroll
and Agramonte). While some parts of Finlay's
theory and his work published in 1881 may
be subject to criticism, yet it is a fact that
at that time (1881) he stated that the microbe
of yellow fever is transmitted from man to
man by the bite of an insect, and that
such an insect could be no other than the
one we now call Aedes aegypti. You have
probably read Finlays original (1881) article,
or extracts of it, so will not go into detail,
but will close it with the fact that Finlay
2
2
gave us the method of experimentation, with all
the details of the technique upon which was
founded the greatest advance in Tropical Medicine
that the world ever knew.

This does not take away any of the credit
due to the American Commission composed of
Reed, Carroll, Lazear and Agramonte, they
proved Finlay's theory. I worked with Carroll and
Agramonte, but not with Reed, because he had to
be in Washington, when the experiments were
being conducted. (Glad you included the “Gentlemen
I salute you” legend, that is not the only legend
that got into public print.) Nor did I work
for Lazear, because unfortunately he died
very early during his work in Cuba

Now to your article, it is very good in
every respect, and notwithstanding my long
years of knowledge on the subject, I see
nothing in your article to criticize

Am familiar with the experiments on
John J. Moran. There seems to be a slight dif
ference in the status of Moran at the time.
The government reports state that he was a
civilian clerk, employed at the headquarters
of Gen Fitzhugh Lee at Quemados, while
you state he was Acting Steward, Army
Hospital Corps, however, this is a small item,
and right or wrong, does not in any way
affect Moran's willingness to volunteer
without any expectation of reward.

I regret that Maj (later Gen) W. C. Gorgas
could not have been included in the picture, but
realize the reason.

Just a few words in regards to myself.
I was called to Havana, Cuba, to take charge
of the Inoculation Station of the Laboratory at
Las Animas Hospital. During my service there
a call was issued for volunteers to submit
to being bitten by supposed yellow fever
infected mosquitoes. It turned out to be a
very risky test, because out of eight volun-
teers, seven got yellow fever, and three of
the seven died from the experiments,
two Spaniards and one American nurse,
Miss Clara Maas. I was lucky to recover
from the experiment, and years later I
find in the list of experiments published
in the Congressional Record and other
papers, that I was classed as an Englishman.
although I was an American at the time
and still am. The above refers to the
experiments conducted by Gen Gorgas and
Dr Guiteras. I was Chief of the Laboratory
of the hospital at the time.

Sorry I did not get your other reprint. If I
knew it had been sent, would try to trace it.
Again, thanking you for the reprint
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely John R. Taylor.
4
4
Postscript
As I was about to seal my letter to you
have just received in my mail a large copy
of the picture "Conquerors of Yellow Fever,"(size 16
by 18) from John Wyeth and Brother of Phila
delphia, also included with it another copy of your
article. Of course I will have the large size
picture framed. It is not only a beautiful work
of art, but also a permanent reminder to me
of the great value to humanity, that the
American Yellow Fever Commission proved
the method of transmission of yellow fever.
Yours sincerely
John R. Taylor.
